questions.question_text: What information is required as part of an interactive ESXi 6.x installation?
Which two statements are true about VMFS5 datastores on ESXi 6.x? (Choose two.)

choices.D: 2MB block size is required to support larger than 2TB file size. AB
choices.A: Virtual Disk (VMDK) size can be larger than 2TB.
choices.B: Datastore extent size can be larger than 2TB.
choices.C: Only Physical Mode Raw Device Map (Passthrough-RDM) can be larger than 2TB.

questions.question_text: Which two actions are required when enabling vFlash Read Cache for a virtual machine's virtual disk? (Choose two.)

choices.C: The Device backing and the block size must be configured.
choices.B: A Flash Resource Pool for Cache size reservation must be entered.
choices.A: A value in the Virtual Flash Read Cache text box must be entered.
choices.D: The Enable virtual flash host swap cache check box must be selected.

discussion.content: Isn't it BC? Nowhere is options AD mentioned - https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-211CE783-51A8-4B65-BFF6-434D1C272308.html OR http://www.yellow-bricks.com/2013/08/26/introduction-to-vsphere-flash-read-cache-aka-vflash/ OR https://www.wojcieh.net/vmware-vflash-read-cache-configuration-and-performance-test/

questions.question_text:
A vSphere Administrator recently upgraded to vSphere .6.5 and wants to assign more than 4 TB of RAM to the virtual machine.
What must happen first?

choices.D: Make sure that there are no snapshots present on the virtual machine. B
choices.B: Upgrade the Virtual Machine compatibility to version 13.
choices.A: Make sure that the user account has administrative privileges at a global level.
choices.C: Obtain an ESXi server with an Intel Skylake CPU.

discussion.content:
Vcenter has nothing to do with Performance of the Storage, also the platform services controller its controlling the services that is related to Vcenter and not the hardware equipments,

So the right answer is B&D

Agree with Rollo and PhanTom. At the bottom of this page it mentions checking for updates and compatibility. No mention of restarting anything. 
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2013160
B&D... Rollo is actually right. vC and PSC have Nothing to do with performances.

choices.C: Verify that vCenter Server is running the latest patched version.
choices.D: Verify that the drivers and firmware are at the recommended versions.
choices.B: Check the VMware Hardware Compatibility List.

questions.question_text:
A vSphere Administrator recently introduced a new shared storage solution for the ESXi hosts. Despite good device specifications, this new storage solution is not performing well.
What are two VMware-recommended troubleshooting steps for fixing this? (Choose two.)
